articles.headline: Delegate Battles Snarl Democrats in Two States
articles.snippet: Fund-raisers for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton are pressuring Democratic Party leaders to resolve an impasse over delegates from Michigan and Florida.
articles.abstract: Fund-raisers for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton are pressuring Democratic Party leaders to resolve an impasse over delegates from Michigan and Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats in Michigan and Florida struggled Friday to resolve the impasse over their disputed January primaries, coming up with a plan to hold a June primary in Michigan while remaining deadlocked in Florida.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Stepping Out After a Makeover
articles.snippet: Lord & Taylor, the 182-year-old department store chain, has, improbably, come roaring back to life. Behind the resurgence is a most unlikely turnaround team.
articles.abstract: Lord & Taylor, the 182-year-old department store chain, has, improbably, come roaring back to life. Behind the resurgence is a most unlikely turnaround team.
articles.lead_paragraph: It loomed just out of reach, a tantalizing prize that Lord & Taylor could not win: Juicy Couture, one of the hottest women’s clothing brands and a best seller in rival stores.

articles.headline: Credit Cards Are Frothy, Not Bubbly
articles.snippet: To a maddening degree, credit card companies will actually do O.K. while the rest of us suffer. Annoying, isn’t it?
articles.abstract: To a maddening degree, credit card companies will actually do O.K. while the rest of us suffer. Annoying, isn’t it?
articles.lead_paragraph: A month ago, BusinessWeek ran a cover article essentially predicting that credit cards would be the next shoe to drop in our increasingly precarious economy. “The party was paid for with credit cards,” read the magazine’s bold cover line. “The hangover will be a whopper.”

articles.headline: A Wall Street Domino Theory
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s unusual decision to assist Bear Stearns underscores a concern that one failure could spread across the financial system.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s unusual decision to assist Bear Stearns underscores a concern that one failure could spread across the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s unusual decision to provide emergency assistance to Bear Stearns underscores a long-building concern that one failure could spread across the financial system.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Eli Lilly E-Mail Discussed Unapproved Use of Drug
articles.snippet: John C. Lechleiter’s 2003 e-mail message appears to have encouraged Eli Lilly to promote its schizophrenia medicine Zyprexa for a use not approved by federal drug regulators.
articles.abstract: John C. Lechleiter’s 2003 e-mail message appears to have encouraged Eli Lilly to promote its schizophrenia medicine Zyprexa for a use not approved by federal drug regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE  John C. Lechleiter, an Eli Lilly official who is about to become the company’s top executive, wrote an e-mail message in 2003 that appears to have encouraged Lilly to promote its schizophrenia medicine Zyprexa for a use not approved by federal drug regulators.

articles.headline: Costs Surge for Stocking the Pantry
articles.snippet: While food costs increased, overall inflation held steady in February as the cost of gasoline declined that month, according to the latest Consumer Price Index.
articles.abstract: While food costs increased, overall inflation held steady in February as the cost of gasoline declined that month, according to the latest Consumer Price Index.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government announced Friday that the cost of food had gone up yet again. This came as no revelation to Bruce Newton, a single father of two children.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Run on Big Wall St. Bank Spurs Rescue Backed by U.S.
articles.snippet: Potential buyers began circling Bear Stearns after it was given a secured line of credit, and policy makers may spend the weekend dealing with the fallout.
articles.abstract: Potential buyers began circling Bear Stearns after it was given a secured line of credit, and policy makers may spend the weekend dealing with the fallout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just three days ago, the head of Bear Stearns, the beleaguered investment bank, sought to assure Wall Street that his firm was safe.

articles.headline: F.D.R.’s Safety Net Gets a Big Stretch
articles.snippet: Bear Stearns was emblematic of a financial system that enabled lenders to evade much of the regulatory framework that had begun during the Roosevelt administration.
articles.abstract: Bear Stearns was emblematic of a financial system that enabled lenders to evade much of the regulatory framework that had begun during the Roosevelt administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was an old-fashioned bank run that forced Bear Stearns to turn to the government for salvation on Friday. The difference is that Bear Stearns is not a commercial bank, and is therefore not eligible for the protections those banks received 75 years ago when Franklin D. Roosevelt halted bank runs with government guarantees.

articles.headline: Prominent Trial Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Bribery
articles.snippet: A plea deal is a remarkable turn for Richard F. Scruggs, a politically well-connected plaintiff’s lawyer who has humbled some of the nation’s most powerful companies.
articles.abstract: A plea deal is a remarkable turn for Richard F. Scruggs, a politically well-connected plaintiff’s lawyer who has humbled some of the nation’s most powerful companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard F. Scruggs, the Mississippi lawyer who built a fortune off asbestos litigation and went on to wring billions from cigarette makers, on Friday ducked what might have been the toughest legal battle of his storied career. Mr. Scruggs pleaded guilty Friday to conspiring to bribe a Mississippi state judge.

articles.headline: Politics Tests a Town Unity Forged by Gunshots
articles.snippet: Kirkwood, Mo., which was drawn together after shootings last month, is now caught up in a leadership struggle.
articles.abstract: Kirkwood, Mo., which was drawn together after shootings last month, is now caught up in a leadership struggle.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIRKWOOD, Mo.  After a shared horror, people in tightknit towns often grow still closer. So no one was surprised when signs began sprouting on the wide lawns here: “Kirkwood stands together, grieves together, heals together.”

articles.headline: Violence in Tibet as Monks Clash With the Police
articles.snippet: The most serious demonstrations China has faced in Tibet since the late 1980s brought reports of at least 10 deaths.
articles.abstract: The most serious demonstrations China has faced in Tibet since the late 1980s brought reports of at least 10 deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Violence erupted Friday morning in a busy market area of the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, as Buddhist monks and other ethnic Tibetans brawled with Chinese security forces in bloody clashes. Witnesses said angry Tibetan crowds burned shops, cars, military vehicles and at least one tourist bus. State media said at least 10 people died.

articles.headline: Measuring Wealth by the Foot
articles.snippet: Supersized yachts are the latest examples of one-upmanship among billionaires.
articles.abstract: Supersized yachts are the latest examples of one-upmanship among billionaires.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN a shipyard in Germany, Blohm & Voss workers are building a mammoth yacht called the Eclipse.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Insurgency Runs on Stolen Oil Profits
articles.snippet: The sea of oil under Iraq is supposed to rebuild the nation, but fuel shipments often get diverted to the black market.
articles.abstract: The sea of oil under Iraq is supposed to rebuild the nation, but fuel shipments often get diverted to the black market.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAIJI, Iraq  The Baiji refinery, with its distillation towers rising against the Hamrin Mountains, may be the most important industrial site in the Sunni Arab-dominated regions of Iraq. On a good day, 500 tanker trucks will leave the refinery filled with fuel with a street value of $10 million.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Shifts Path, Inventing Policy in Crisis
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke, who has long argued that a central bank should act on consistent principles, now has to improvise.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, who has long argued that a central bank should act on consistent principles, now has to improvise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke has long argued that a central bank should base its policies as much as possible on consistent principles rather than seat-of-the-pants judgment.

articles.headline: Rescue Me: A Fed Bailout Crosses a Line
articles.snippet: The Fed’s effort to bail out Bear Stearns could have ugly consequences.
articles.abstract: The Fed’s effort to bail out Bear Stearns could have ugly consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHAT are the consequences of a world in which regulators rescue even the financial institutions whose recklessness and greed helped create the titanic credit mess we are in? Will the consequences be an even weaker currency, rampant inflation, a continuation of the slow bleed that we have witnessed at banks and brokerage firms for the past year?

articles.headline: Barry Diller Conquered. Now He Tries to Divide.
articles.snippet: IAC/InteractiveCorp, Barry Diller’s collection of Internet-focused companies including Ticketmaster and Expedia, is floundering.
articles.abstract: IAC/InteractiveCorp, Barry Diller’s collection of Internet-focused companies including Ticketmaster and Expedia, is floundering.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Jim Collins, author of “Good to Great,” a guidebook for corporate makeovers, spoke at an executive retreat two years ago for IAC/InterActiveCorp, the company’s founder, Barry Diller, took advantage of the occasion to poke fun at himself.
articles.byline: By Geraldine Fabrikant and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: For Democrats, Increased Fears of a Long Fight
articles.snippet: Many superdelegates cite the will of the voters as a guiding principle, a boon to Senator Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: Many superdelegates cite the will of the voters as a guiding principle, a boon to Senator Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Lacking a clear route to the selection of a Democratic presidential nominee, the party’s uncommitted superdelegates say they are growing increasingly concerned about the risks of a prolonged fight between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, and perplexed about how to resolve the conflict.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Cutting Dosage of Costly Drug Spurs a Debate
articles.snippet: A drug for a rare enzyme deficiency can cost $300,000 a year, making the right dose a matter of public debate.
articles.abstract: A drug for a rare enzyme deficiency can cost $300,000 a year, making the right dose a matter of public debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a drug can cost more than $300,000 a year, the right dose becomes a matter of public debate.

articles.headline: Dusting Off the Archive for the Web
articles.snippet: For magazines and newspapers with long histories, old material can be reborn on the Web as an inexpensive way to attract readers, advertisers and money.
articles.abstract: For magazines and newspapers with long histories, old material can be reborn on the Web as an inexpensive way to attract readers, advertisers and money.
articles.lead_paragraph: As magazines and newspapers hunt for the new thing they need to be to thrive in the Internet era, some find that part of the answer lies in the old thing they used to be.

articles.headline: Does This Latte Have a Funny Mainstream Taste to You?
articles.snippet: Critics say Starbucks has squandered its musical tastemaking cachet by offering more mainstream selections in its coffee shops.
articles.abstract: Critics say Starbucks has squandered its musical tastemaking cachet by offering more mainstream selections in its coffee shops.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2005, Starbucks looked like it was going to do for undiscovered music what it had done for the nonfat latte. The company decided to stock “Careless Love,” a CD of sophisticated pop-jazz songs by Madeleine Peyroux, who had attracted only a modest following in this country, plying her craft in small bars. Ms. Peyroux soon found herself at No. 81 on the Billboard chart, and has become a mainstay of jazz.

articles.headline: Alitalia Takes Offer for Buyout
articles.snippet: Alitalia, the money-losing Italian airline, accepted a 747 million-euro takeover offer from Air France-KLM on Sunday, seizing an 11th-hour financial lifeline.
articles.abstract: Alitalia, the money-losing Italian airline, accepted a 747 million-euro takeover offer from Air France-KLM on Sunday, seizing an 11th-hour financial lifeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The board of Alitalia, the money-losing Italian airline, accepted a 747 million-euro takeover offer from Air France-KLM on Sunday, seizing a financial lifeline at the 11th hour after months of political indecision and labor resistance.

articles.headline: Fears That Bear Stearns’s Downfall May Spread
articles.snippet: Investors are bracing for another volatile week in the markets as bankers and policy makers deal with the fallout from their bid to rescue Bear Stearns.
articles.abstract: Investors are bracing for another volatile week in the markets as bankers and policy makers deal with the fallout from their bid to rescue Bear Stearns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cash squeeze that brought Bear Stearns to its knees is fanning fears that other investment banks might be vulnerable to the crisis of confidence gripping Wall Street.

articles.headline: JP Morgan Pays $2 a Share for Bear Stearns
articles.snippet: In a shocking deal reached on Sunday to save Bear Stearns, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday.
articles.abstract: In a shocking deal reached on Sunday to save Bear Stearns, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a shocking deal reached on Sunday to save Bear Stearns, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay a mere $2 a share to buy all of Bear  less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday.

articles.headline: More Than a Sound Bite, This Clip Has Some Teeth
articles.snippet: A Barack Obama supporter quizzed on the street has drawn a million views on YouTube.
articles.abstract: A Barack Obama supporter quizzed on the street has drawn a million views on YouTube.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Jan. 31, Derrick Ashong, a 32-year-old musician, dropped off his pal, Shaunelle Curry, at the Democratic primary debate taking place at the Kodak Theater in Hollywood. After shrugging off her suggestion that he join her in carrying a sign for Barack Obama outside the theater  his band was leaving on tour the next day  he reconsidered and walked back to join her.

articles.headline: Curbs on Protest in Tibet Lashed by Dalai Lama
articles.snippet: The Dalai Lama accused China of waging “cultural genocide” against his followers in Tibet.
articles.abstract: The Dalai Lama accused China of waging “cultural genocide” against his followers in Tibet.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHARAMSALA, India  The Dalai Lama accused China on Sunday of waging “cultural genocide” against his followers in Tibet and called for an international inquiry into the suppression of protests there, his strongest defense to date of Tibetan Buddhists who have staged an uprising against Chinese rule.

articles.headline: Open-Source Troubles in Wiki World
articles.snippet: A shoestring operation stunned by its own success faces growing pains.
articles.abstract: A shoestring operation stunned by its own success faces growing pains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since he helped create Wikipedia in 2001, Jimmy Wales has been called many things: benevolent dictator, constitutional monarch, digital evangelist and spiritual leader of the tens of thousands of volunteers who have made the online encyclopedia one of the top 10 most visited Web sites.

articles.headline: World Banker and His Cash Return Home
articles.snippet: Dilip Ratha, who has gone from a village in India to the World Bank, knows the economics of migration firsthand.
articles.abstract: Dilip Ratha, who has gone from a village in India to the World Bank, knows the economics of migration firsthand.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINDHEKELA, India  An important man from the World Bank recently arrived in this isolated village, where monkeys prowl rutted roads, rain pours through the school roof and the native son who achieved the most did so by going away.

articles.headline: Fateful Choice on Iraq Army Bypassed Debate
articles.snippet: The decision by L. Paul Bremer III to dissolve Iraq’s Army was a reversal from a plan the White House had approved.
articles.abstract: The decision by L. Paul Bremer III to dissolve Iraq’s Army was a reversal from a plan the White House had approved.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  When President Bush convened a meeting of his National Security Council on May 22, 2003, his special envoy in Iraq made a statement that caught many of the participants by surprise. In a video presentation from Baghdad, L. Paul Bremer III informed the president and his aides that he was about to issue an order formally dissolving Iraq’s Army.

articles.headline: Fed Acts to Rescue Financial Markets
articles.snippet: The Fed approved a $30 billion loan for the takeover of Bear Stearns and announced a new lending tool for investment firms.
articles.abstract: The Fed approved a $30 billion loan for the takeover of Bear Stearns and announced a new lending tool for investment firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Hoping to avoid a systemic meltdown in financial markets, the Federal Reserve on Sunday approved a $30 billion credit line to engineer the takeover of Bear Stearns and announced an open-ended lending program for the biggest investment firms on Wall Street.
